a: A software system used to create, manage, and provide controlled access to databases.
Data is raw facts; Information is processed data that provides context and meaning.
The ability to modify a schema definition in one level without affecting the schema definition in the next higher level (Physical vs. Logical).
External Level (User views), Conceptual Level (Logical design), and Internal Level (Physical storage).

q: What is a Relation in DBMS?
a: A table with columns (attributes) and rows (tuples).
A unique identifier for each record in a table; it cannot contain NULL values.
An attribute in one table that refers to the Primary Key of another table, establishing a relationship.
A minimal set of attributes that can uniquely identify a tuple in a relation.
A set of one or more attributes that taken collectively allows us to identify uniquely a tuple in the relation.
A primary key that consists of more than one attribute.
A system-generated unique identifier (like an auto-incremented ID) that has no business meaning.
NOT NULL, UNIQUE, PRIMARY KEY, FOREIGN KEY, CHECK, DEFAULT.

q: Name basic operations in Relational Algebra.
a: Selection ($\sigma$), Projection ($\pi$), Union ($\cup$), Set Difference ($-$), Cartesian Product ($\times$), and Rename ($\rho$).
A 'thing' or 'object' in the real world that is distinguishable from all other objects.
An entity that does not have a primary key of its own and depends on a strong entity for its existence.
Specifies the number of instances of one entity that can be associated with instances of another entity (1:1, 1:N, M:N).
DDL (Data Definition Language) defines structure (CREATE, ALTER, DROP). DML (Data Manipulation Language) handles data (SELECT, INSERT, UPDATE, DELETE).

q: What is the difference between DELETE and TRUNCATE?
a: DELETE is DML (can be rolled back, uses WHERE). TRUNCATE is DDL (cannot be rolled back, resets identity, faster).

q: What is the difference between DROP and TRUNCATE?
a: DROP removes the table and its definition. TRUNCATE removes all rows but keeps the table structure.
Functions that perform a calculation on a set of values (SUM, AVG, MIN, MAX, COUNT).
WHERE filters rows before grouping. HAVING filters groups after the GROUP BY clause.
Returns records that have matching values in both tables.
Returns all records from the left table and matched records from the right table; unmatched right rows result in NULL.

q: What is a Full Outer Join?
a: Returns all records when there is a match in either left or right table.
Produces a Cartesian product of the two tables.
A regular join where a table is joined with itself.
A query nested inside another query (Inner query vs Outer query).
Non-correlated subqueries can run independently. Correlated subqueries depend on the outer query for their values.
UNION removes duplicate rows. UNION ALL keeps all rows including duplicates.
A virtual table based on the result-set of an SQL statement.
A view that physically stores the query result and is updated periodically.
Process of organizing data to minimize redundancy and dependency by dividing large tables into smaller ones.
Atomicity: Each column must contain atomic (indivisible) values; no repeating groups.
Must be in 1NF and all non-key attributes must be fully functionally dependent on the primary key (No partial dependency).
Must be in 2NF and no non-key attribute should be transitively dependent on the primary key.
Boyce-Codd Normal Form. For every functional dependency $X \rightarrow Y$, $X$ must be a super key.
A constraint that specifies the relationship between two sets of attributes where one set uniquely determines the other ($X \rightarrow Y$).
Atomicity, Consistency, Isolation, Durability.
The 'All or Nothing' property; either the entire transaction succeeds or it is completely rolled back.
Ensures that concurrent transactions do not interfere with each other; they appear to execute serially.
Once a transaction is committed, the changes are permanent even in case of system failure.
A file that records all changes made to a database to ensure recovery in case of failure.
When a transaction reads data that has been modified by another transaction but not yet committed.
When a transaction reads the same row twice and gets different data because another transaction modified it in between.
When a transaction re-runs a query returning a set of rows and finds additional rows added by another committed transaction.
Read Uncommitted, Read Committed, Repeatable Read, Serializable.
A data structure that improves the speed of data retrieval operations at the cost of slower writes and additional storage.
Clustered: Determines the physical order of data in the table (1 per table). Non-clustered: Separate structure containing pointers to data (multiple allowed).
A self-balancing tree data structure that keeps data sorted and allows searches, sequential access, insertions, and deletions in logarithmic time.
Uses a hash table to find entries; very fast for equality (=) comparisons but useless for range queries.

q: What is a Deadlock in DBMS?
a: A situation where two or more transactions are waiting indefinitely for each other to release locks.
A protocol ensuring serializability. It has a Growing phase (obtaining locks) and a Shrinking phase (releasing locks).
A prepared SQL code that you can save and reuse.
A special type of stored procedure that automatically runs when an event (INSERT, UPDATE, DELETE) occurs in the database.
Non-SQL or Not Only SQL; provides a mechanism for storage and retrieval of data modeled in formats other than tabular relations.
Document, Key-Value, Column-family, Graph.
Basically Available, Soft state, Eventual consistency (used in NoSQL).
Horizontal partitioning of data across multiple servers or databases.
Storing copies of data on multiple nodes to ensure high availability and fault tolerance.
A control structure that enables traversal over the records in a database result set.
The process of adding redundant data to a normalized database to improve read performance.
Database: Optimized for OLTP (Transactional). Data Warehouse: Optimized for OLAP (Analytical/Historical).
Extract, Transform, Load: Process of moving data from source systems to a data warehouse.
A vulnerability where an attacker can interfere with the queries an application makes to its database.
Returns the first non-null value in a list.
Rank leaves gaps in sequences after ties. Dense_Rank does not leave gaps.
Common Table Expression; a temporary named result set defined within the execution scope of a single query.
Duplication of data in multiple places, which can lead to inconsistency and wasted space.

q: What is an Anomaly in DBMS?
a: Issues (Insertion, Deletion, Update) that arise in poorly designed, unnormalized databases.
An attribute that can have more than one value for a single entity instance (e.g., Phone Number).
An attribute whose value is calculated from other attributes (e.g., Age from Date of Birth).
Ensures that a value in a foreign key column must match a value in the referenced primary key column or be NULL.
Used in WHERE clause to search for a specified pattern in a column (using % and _).

q: What is the purpose of the 'AS' keyword?
a: Used to give a table or a column a temporary name (Alias).

q: What is the difference between IN and BETWEEN?
a: IN matches a value against a list of discrete values. BETWEEN matches against a range of values.
A point within a transaction to which you can roll back without rolling back the entire transaction.
Commit saves changes permanently. Rollback undoes changes since the start of the transaction or last savepoint.
Shared (S): Allows multiple transactions to read. Exclusive (X): Only one transaction can write/read.
A property ensuring that joining the decomposed tables results in the original table without any extra or missing tuples.
Ensures that all functional dependencies of the original relation are satisfied in the decomposed relations.
An index on two or more columns of a table.
An index that contains an entry for only some of the search-key values (usually one per data block).
An index that contains an entry for every search-key value in the data file.
The process of choosing the most efficient way (execution plan) to execute an SQL statement.
A database where portions are stored in multiple physical locations, processing is distributed across multiple nodes.
Used to test for the existence of any record in a subquery.
Used with LIMIT to skip a specified number of rows before starting to return rows.
Procedures can have DML/DDL and don't require a return. Functions must return a value and are generally for computation.
In a distributed system, you can only provide two out of: Consistency, Availability, Partition Tolerance.
Stores data as JSON, BSON, or XML documents (e.g., MongoDB).
GRANT gives permissions to users. REVOKE takes them back.
The logical representation/blueprint of the entire database.
The actual data stored in a database at a particular moment in time.
Defines the valid values for a column (Data type, Range, Format).
Similar to a join but used for joining a table to a table-valued function.
Occurs when indexes have many gaps or pages are out of logical order, reducing performance.
Must be in BCNF and have no multi-valued dependencies.
Uses graph structures (nodes, edges, properties) to represent and store data (e.g., Neo4j).
Increasing capacity by adding more power (CPU, RAM) to an existing server.
Increasing capacity by adding more servers to the pool.

q: What is the use of the 'NULLIF' function?
a: Returns NULL if the two arguments are equal; otherwise returns the first argument.
Assumes multiple transactions can complete without affecting each other; checks for conflicts before committing.
Locks data immediately so that no other transaction can modify it until the lock is released.
A crash where the contents of main memory (volatile) are lost, but disk contents (non-volatile) survive.
A mechanism where all the log records and dirty data blocks are flushed from memory to disk to reduce recovery time.
An index that contains all the columns needed for a specific query, so the database doesn't need to look up the table.
Inheritance/Sub-typing in ER modeling (e.g., Student IS A Person).
Specialization: Top-down (breaking entity into sub-entities). Generalization: Bottom-up (combining sub-entities into one).
Returns only the rows that are common to both SELECT statements.
Returns rows from the first SELECT statement that are not present in the second SELECT statement.
Data about data; describes the structure, constraints, and properties of the data.
The person responsible for managing, securing, and maintaining the database system.
Functions that perform calculations across a set of table rows that are related to the current row (e.g., OVER clause).
A DBMS that runs on multiple processors/disks designed to execute operations in parallel to improve performance.
When a non-prime attribute depends on only part of a composite primary key.
When a non-prime attribute depends on another non-prime attribute ($A \rightarrow B \rightarrow C$).
Consistency: All nodes see same data at same time. Eventual: Nodes will eventually converge to same state after some time.
A data modeling style with a central fact table surrounded by dimension tables (used in Data Warehousing).
An extension of star schema where dimension tables are normalized into multiple related tables.
SQL's way of handling if-then-else logic within a query.
An aggregate function that concatenates strings from a group into a single string with a delimiter.
Extremely large data sets that may be analyzed computationally to reveal patterns, trends, and associations.
A software architecture in which a single instance of software serves multiple customers (tenants).
A highly scalable, high-performance distributed NoSQL database (Column-family).
An in-memory data structure store, used as a database, cache, and message broker (Key-Value).
The process of obscuring specific data elements within a database to protect sensitive information.
Securing data that is stored on physical media (disks, tapes) so it cannot be read if the hardware is stolen.
A repository that contains information about the structure of the database (metadata).
The process of changing the database schema over time while preserving existing data.
Using different data storage technologies to handle different data storage needs within the same application.
Using the DISTINCT keyword.
The process of the DBMS periodically checking for cycles in the wait-for graph and aborting a transaction to break the cycle.
A named column of a relation.
A row of a relation.

q: Why use an Index if it slows down writes?
a: Because in most applications, read operations far outnumber write operations, and the performance gain in searching justifies the cost.
